A copy of the final report was submitted to us as a supplementary tribunal document.

The land council withdrew both of its applications before this tribunal on 20 February 1998. On 15 March 1998, Zen Pearls and Indian Pacific Pearls applied for new permits. On 19 March 1998 the applicants lodged applications to “increase area from original 10 ha to 60 ha as per map supplied and original application”.

On 22 September 1998 a site inspection meeting was held on Palm Island. A transcript was taken from which it is apparent that among those present were Michael Crimp, Walter Palm Island, Erykah Kyle, Eric Bunn, Violet Sirris and other people from Palm Island, Clive Cook, Chris Robinson and Phil Hayles from the authority, and Michael Baer and Nicolaas Heijm.

On 24 September 1998 the Manbarra elders passed a resolution confirming opposition to the presence of both pearl farms. That decision, according to Mr Heijm, was based on the historical and cultural significance of the Juno Bay site for both the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples, the sense of trespass on traditional ownership rights, concerns that the cultural connection to the area would slip away and a strong feeling that the provision of a small number of employment opportunities offered by the pearling operations would not adequately compensate the damage to cultural values.

In late December 1998 a consultation process was agreed between the traditional owners and the authority. On 14 January 1999 the authority provided the Gabulbarra reference group with Mr Heijm’s report. On 1 March 1999, Jonas Rupp, Project Manager of Environment Impact Management at the authority, wrote to the Gabulbarra reference group. He noted that the consultation process had been agreed and completed. He suggested a meeting and asked for written clarification of issues to be discussed at a meeting by 15 March 1999. Mr Rupp of the authority wrote to the reference group again on 15 March 1999, setting a final deadline for submissions for 2 April 1999 and leaving open the option of a meeting. On 13 April 1999, Mr Baer faxed the authority a letter dated 12 April 1999 from the group (Walter Palm Island, Bonita Mabo and Violet Sirriss) asking the authority to refuse to grant the permits.

On 9 April 1999 the land council wrote to the authority making several submissions about the “decision making criteria set out in” the Regulations. These included a submission on “Cultural Heritage values”. The land council wrote again on 13 April 1999.

On 12 May 1999 the authority, by its delegate Mr Cook, decided that a permit should be granted to Indian Pacific Pearls and that Zen Pearls’ application should be refused. He produced a statement of reasons on 25 June 1999. The land council sought internal review on 23 July 1999. The decision was affirmed by Richard Kenchington on 1 September 1999. A statement of reasons was produced on 13 August 2001.

heading.title: Part 1.8: Consultation with the Palm Island community

p.text: Mr Crimp criticised the effectiveness of the community consultation processes that had been initially undertaken by the authority. It was his contention that sufficient numbers of Manbarra and Bwgcolman elders had been consulted to form an opinion and for the “Palm Island grapevine” to inform others who had not been consulted. Mr Crimp contended that throughout the consultation process negotiations were carried out in good faith. However, the Manbarra People had not supplied particulars on their standing and other matters.

It was Mr Crimp’s further submission that consultation, in the context of application for a permit from the authority, was adequate. Mr Crimp submitted that based on his reliance on the report prepared by Adrian Pryor, permission had been sought and given. Moreover, Mr Crimp submitted that any claim of lack of respect by him to the Palm Island People could be rebutted as he had followed the protocols for permission to use the country.
Mr Crimp further contended:
that the Palm Island Council had been fully informed about the whole proposal; and
that Manbarra had not been formally named or recognised at the time of the council general meeting on 15 May 1996.

Mr Preston contended that the Palm Island Council had not acted in accordance with the Aboriginal customs and practices of the area because it acted without consulting the Manbarra People. He submitted that the council had acted contrary to the actual views of the Manbarra People. He submitted that the Palm Island Council could only exercise statutory functions and powers provided under the Community Services (Aborigines) Act 1984 (Qld). These functions and powers did not extend to the council conveying community opinion in respect of matters outside its council area. The council area did not include the sea.
Mr Preston further submitted that the Manbarra People had consistently opposed the grant of permits for the pearl farm operation from the time that permits were first granted.

Mr Heijm considered that it was well recognised that it took time for the development of a consensus opinion within an Aboriginal community such as the Palm Island community and this was probably the reason community values appeared to change over a 12-month period.

It was Mr Heijm’s opinion that the consensual opinion forming process by the Palm Island People took time in order to consider all of the issues that were essential to decide whether assent should be given to the pearl farm proposal. He stated that it would be unlikely that consensus, in the factual circumstances of the pearl farm proposal, could have been achieved over a short time period, for example, a few days or a week. It was his opinion that it would take 9 or more months in order to develop a consensus within the community for the pearl farm proposal. Furthermore, a public meeting of elders was necessary in order to get a definitive statement of public opinion.
To Mr Heijm’s knowledge there were no Manbarra People who had been members of the Palm Island Council, but there had certainly been Bwgcolman elders who had been members of the council.

In response to a tribunal question he said that the members of the Palm Island community were unaware of the letter sent to the authority by the Palm Island Council on or about 11 June 1996 which stated that the council approved the pearl farm proposal. Mr Heijm said that “[n]obody outside the Council knew of it at the time, and that was considered to be very improper by the elders on Palm Island”.

heading.title: Part 2.1: The central section zoning plan

p.text: A zoning plan is in force for the central section of the park pursuant to ss 32, 33 and 36 of the Act. The plan divides the central section into six zones:
central use “A” zone;
central use “B” zone;
Marine National Park “A” zone;
Marine National Park “B” zone;
scientific research zone;
preservation zone.

Earlier listed zones require less protection than later listed zones. The bulk of the Harrier Point site is general use “A” and the Juno Bay site is general use “B”. This can be seen from the map set out above in which the lighter shading is general use “A” and the heavier shading is general use “B”.
The objective for the general use “A” zone under the zoning plan is:
To provide opportunities for reasonable general-use consistent with the conservation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.
The objective for the general use “B” zone under the zoning plan is:
To provide for the conservation of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park while providing opportunities for reasonable general-use in areas that are free from trawling and generally free from shipping.

Clauses 5.2 and 6.2 of the zoning plan set out “the only purposes for which” the general use “A” zone and general use “B” zone respectively “may be used or entered”. There then appears in each case a list of purposes describing various types of fishing, gathering and other recreational activities. The list is identical for both zones except that “trawling” is excluded from the general use “B” zone. These permitted purposes are qualified by the introductory words “unless otherwise stated in paragraph (b)”. In both cases para (b) describes purposes permitted “with the written permission of the authority or its delegate”. The purposes include the following three purposes in both zones:
the farming of marine resources including the operation, construction, maintenance, demolition or removal of any associated facility;
the construction or conduct of mooring facilities for vessels;
[(xviii) in 5.2 and (xix) in 6.2] any purpose not listed in this clause, consistent with the objectives of the zone.
The purposes of the Act include the protection of the park. Section 5(1) of the Act provides that the object of the Act is:
… to make provision for and in relation to the establishment, control, care and development of a marine park in the Great Barrier Reef Region in accordance with the provisions of this Act …

It is clear from s 5(1) of the Act that the focus of the legislation, after the establishment of the park, is its care, control and development. This includes the taking of steps to preserve the park and what is contained within it including, but not limited to, the reef: see Ashton v Commonwealth (2003) 126 FCR 297 at [21] .

Further reference is made in s 32(7) of the Act to the object of conservation of the Great Barrier Reef, to the regulation and use of the park to aid its protection, and the regulation of activities to minimise their effects on it. Section 32(7)(b) provides that, in the preparation of a “zoning plan”, regard is to be had to the object of:
… the regulation of the use of the Marine Park so as to protect the Great Barrier Reef while allowing the reasonable use of the Great Barrier Reef Region …

heading.title: Part 2.3: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations 1983 (Cth)

p.text: Regulation 18(4) (formerly reg 13AC(4)) prescribes the relevant matters that must be considered for the grant of a permit to use or enter the park:
In considering an application for a relevant permission, the Authority must have regard to:
the objective of the zone; and
the need to protect the cultural and heritage values held in relation to the Marine Park by traditional inhabitants and other people; and
the likely effect of granting permission on future options for the Marine Park; and
the conservation of the natural resources of the Marine Park; and
the nature and scale of the proposed use in relation to the existing use and amenity, and the future or desirable use and amenity, of the relevant area and of nearby areas; and
the likely effects of the proposed use on adjoining and adjacent areas and any possible effects of the proposed use on the environment and the adequacy of safeguards for the environment; and

the means of transport for entry into, use within or departure from the zone or designated area and the adequacy of provisions for aircraft or vessel mooring, landing, taking off, parking, loading and unloading; and
in relation to any structure, landing area, farming facility, vessel or work to which the proposed use relates:
the health and safety aspects involved, including the adequacy of construction; and

the arrangements for removal upon the expiration of the permission of the structure, landing area, farming facility or vessel or any other thing that is to be built, assembled, constructed or fixed in position as a result of that use; and
the arrangements for making good any damage caused to the Marine Park by the proposed activity; and
any other requirements for ensuring the orderly and proper management of the Marine Park; and
any charge payable by the applicant in relation to a chargeable permission (whether or not in force) that is overdue for payment; and
if the application relates to an undeveloped project, the cost of which will be large — the capacity of the applicant to satisfactorily develop the project. [Emphasis added]

Of particular significance for administrative decision-making under reg 18(4) is the use of the phrase “have regard to”. In R v Toohey; Ex parte Meneling Station Pty Ltd (1982) 158 CLR 327 at 333 ; 44 ALR 63 at 67 , Gibbs CJ said:
It [the phrase “have regard to”] requires [the commissioner] to take those matters into account and give weight to them as a fundamental element in making his recommendation.
See also Re Mohr and Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (1998) 53 ALD 635 .

Accordingly, the phrase “must have regard to” can be seen to specify matters which must be considered under reg 18(4). In its statement of reasons, the authority considered each of the matters specified in reg 18(4) in arriving at its decision to refuse to grant a permit to Zen Pearls at the Juno Bay site. The matters particularly referred to before us were reg 18(4)(a), (b) and (e).
The formal powers and discretions vested in the original decision-maker for the purposes of making a decision on an application for a permit are prescribed in reg 22:
(1) Where a person has made an application for a relevant permission and has complied with any requirement or request duly made by the Authority in relation to the application, the Authority shall:
grant such permission in writing; or
by notice in writing given to that person, refuse to grant such permission.
(2) A relevant permission may be granted subject to such conditions (if any) as the Authority specifies in the permission, being:
conditions allowing the giving of authorities and specifying the maximum number of persons to whom authorities may be given; and
conditions indemnifying the Authority in respect of costs to the Authority that the permission holder’s activities might incur; and
conditions appropriate to the attainment of the object of the Act (including a requirement that the person give the Authority a written undertaking in a form approved by the Authority) …
(4) A relevant permission remains in force for such period as is specified in the permission unless it is sooner surrendered or revoked.

heading.title: Part 2.3.1: reg 18(4)(a): Objective of the zone

p.text: This phrase is used in the objective specified for both relevant zones in the zoning plan. US courts have considered the concept of “reasonable use” in natural resource contexts, and in particular where riparian rights are involved. The decision of the Supreme Court of Michigan in Thompson v Enz 154 NW 2d (1967) at 473, “is the case most relied upon by the district court in its reasonable use analysis”: see Stupak-Thrall v United States (89 F 3d 1269) (6th Cir 23 July 1996) 27 ELR 20,001 at 20,013. In its analysis the court concluded that a number of elements needed to be considered in determining “reasonable use”. First, it was necessary for attention to be given to the site and its attributes, including its size, character and natural state. Second, there was a need to examine the use itself in terms of its type, extent, necessity and effects. Finally, it was necessary to examine the proposed artificial use in relation to the consequential effects, including the benefits obtained and the detriment suffered, on the interests of others as well as the interests of the state.

heading.title: Part 2.3.2: reg 18(4)(b): Cultural and heritage values

p.text: The term “traditional inhabitants” is not defined in the Act. However, the zoning plan defines “traditional inhabitant” to mean:
An Aboriginal or Islander who lives in an area or areas in accordance with Aboriginal or Islander tradition, respectively.
Definitions in the zoning plan are described as applying “in the Zoning Plan”.

In Chapman v Luminis Pty Ltd (No 4) (2001) 123 FCR 62 , von Doussa J considered the notion of “Aboriginal tradition” as defined in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (Cth) in which “Aboriginal tradition” means:

The body of traditions, observances, customs and beliefs of Aboriginals generally or of a particular community or group of Aboriginals, and includes any such traditions, observances, customs or beliefs relating to particular persons, areas, objects or relationships.
von Doussa J made the following observations in relation to the meaning of the words “traditions, observances, customs and beliefs” (at 143–4):

I accept that the definition does require a degree of antiquity to the traditions, observances, customs and beliefs. The [Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act], by its title, is in respect of heritage protection. The Australian Oxford Dictionary (1999) defines “heritage” to mean “anything that is or may be inherited”. The notion of tradition is the handing down of beliefs, legends and customs from generation to generation, especially by word of mouth or by practice. See generally the discussion of the notion of tradition in Commonwealth v Yarmirr (1999) 101 FCR 171 at 194 [65] and in Members of the Yorta Yorta Aboriginal Community v Victoria (2001) 110 FCR 244 at 254–60 [27]–[49] and 267–8 [110]–[122]. The words “observances, customs, or beliefs” are perhaps not so readily understood as importing a degree of antiquity. However, the definitions of each of the words in this expression in the Macquarie Dictionary (3rd ed, 1998) indicates that, standing alone, the words do have this connotation. “Observance” is defined as: “the action of conforming to, obeying or following. A keeping or celebration by appropriate procedure, ceremonies etc. A rule of custom to be observed.” A “custom” is defined as: “an habitual practice; the usual way of acting in given circumstances … a group pattern of habitual activity usually transmitted from one generation to another.” A “belief” is defined as: “that which is believed, an accepted opinion.” Taken in conjunction, the words in the expression “traditions, observances, customs or beliefs” carry with them the notion that there has been a handing down from generation to generation in accordance with the accepted understanding of the way in which Aboriginal history, laws, observances and practices have been transmitted through the aeons. [Emphasis added]

Lockhart J made the following observations on “Aboriginal tradition and burial sites” in Wamba Wamba Local Aboriginal Land Council v Minister Administering the Aboriginal Heritage Protection Act 1984 (1989) 23 FCR 239 at 249–50 ; 86 ALR 161 at 172 ; 18 ALD 268 at 271 :

There is one final observation which I propose to make. The circumstances that arose here are almost insoluble. On the one hand there is the claim of the Aboriginal people requiring that burial places remain peaceful, tranquil and undisturbed by human beings. This observance of Aboriginal tradition is not confined to the formal boundaries of the second respondent’s development of bowling greens and club houses but obviously relates to areas of land, in particular the large mound or sand dune being the high point in the land which the second respondent has chosen for the site of its club house, bowling greens and other substantial facilities for use as a golf club and country club …

Aboriginal tradition requires that burial places remain peaceful and tranquil and must not be walked upon or otherwise intruded upon by human beings. They are the places which Aboriginals believe are the place of the spirits waiting to be called back, and, if the spirits are disturbed, the Aboriginal people believe that they will suffer because of the failure to care for them. There is no doubt that the Aboriginal community are disturbed and distressed by the actions of the second respondent and will continue to be disturbed if the club house and bowling greens are constructed on their proposed sites even if the northern bowling green is moved to a different site or not constructed at all on any part of the land of the second respondent. [Emphasis added]
Traditional fishing is defined in the zoning plan to mean:
fishing; otherwise than for purposes of recreation, sale or trade, in an area by a traditional inhabitant or a group of traditional inhabitants.
A similar meaning is given to “traditional hunting and gathering”.

These definitions are not relevant to any applicable provision in the zoning plan although they do appear in descriptions of purposes authorised in both relevant zones. Fishing, using no more than six hooks per line, and spear-fishing, without underwater breathing apparatus which is not commercial, does not require permission.

Some of the cases have given a more limited meaning to expressions such as “traditional fishing”. In Sutton v Derschaw (1995) 82 A Crim R 318 , a case dealing with Aboriginal fishing rights, Heenan J relied upon comments made by Gleeson CJ in Mason v Tritton (1994) 34 NSWLR 572 at 574 that:

Fishing is an activity which is so natural … that some care needs to be exercised in passing from an observation that people have engaged in that activity to an assertion that they are members of a class who have exercised some form of right pursuant to a system of rules recognised by the common law.

Justice Heenan (at 6, 7) also relied upon comments by Kirby P in the Tritton case that a “right to fish” based upon traditional laws and customs is a recognisable form of native title defended by the common law of Australia, but that its evidentiary requirements were exacting, and required:
that traditional laws and customs extending the “right to fish” were exercised by an Aboriginal community immediately before the Crown claimed sovereignty over the territory …
that the appellant is an indigenous person and is a biological descendant of that original Aboriginal community;
that the appellant and the intermediate descendants had, subject to the general propositions outlined above, continued, uninterrupted, to observe the relevant traditional laws and customs; and
that the appellant’s activity or conduct in fishing for (the fish in question) was an exercise of those traditional laws and customs.

The inclusion of “other people” within the group to be protected by reg 18(4)(b) shows that the cultural and heritage values encompassed by the regulation are not confined to the values of traditional inhabitants. It follows that the cultural and heritage values of traditional inhabitants protected by the regulation are not confined to traditional cultural and heritage values. The protected cultural and heritage values of traditional inhabitants can include values with European or other origins provided they qualify to be described as cultural and heritage values.

The term “cultural and heritage values” is not defined in the Act. In Tickner v Bropho (1993) 40 FCR 183 ; 114 ALR 409 , French J made the following observations on “cultural heritage” (at FCR 211 ; ALR 437 ):

The contemporary Australian landscape is laced with the beautiful and intricate patterns of the Aboriginal Dreamtime mythology. That mythology is a priceless part of our national cultural heritage. Its fragility in conflict with the political imperatives of Commonwealth and State Governments is highlighted in this case.

The preservation of human cultural heritage as a public duty is recognised in the laws of many nations. The concept is said to have originated in 19th France: Sax, “Heritage Preservation as Public Duty: The Abbe Gregoire and the Origins of an Idea” (1990) 88 Michigan Law Review 1142. The duty is recognised at international law by the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage to which Australia is a party. The cultural heritage of any country extends to the language, traditions, customs, stories and religions of its peoples past and present. The drive to preserve that heritage sometimes conflicts with other perceived public interests which involve its destruction or impairment. [Emphasis added]

The term “amenity” is not defined in the Act. However, its meaning has been considered judicially. The ordinary meaning of the word is reflected in the following passage from the judgment of O’Bryan J in Melbourne City Council v Silver Top Taxi Service Ltd (1994) 89 LGERA 387 at 390 :

Amenity is an ordinary English word meaning “the quality of being pleasant or agreeable”; “the more human and pleasurable environmental aspects of a house, factory etc”; “pleasant places and scenes” ( Oxford Dictionary).

The meaning of “amenity” in the context of town planning has been considered in a number of cases. In Broad v Brisbane City Council and Baptist Union of Queensland [1986] 2 Qd R 317 ; (1986) 59 LGRA 296 de Jersey J said (at Qd R 326 ; LGRA 304–5 ):
In Cecil E Mayo Pty Ltd v Sydney City Council (1952) 18 LGR 152 at 156 Sugerman J described the amenity of a neighbourhood as “the quality which it has of being pleasant or agreeable”.

One would think that the assessment of that quality would necessarily involve subjective judgments, and often judgments for which it would be difficult to offer a rational, concrete foundation. In Balgowlah Investments Ltd v Manly Municipal Council, supra, he suggested that central to the significance of apprehended injury to amenity is the question of what residents are “justly entitled to expect”. But that question is ordinarily not to be answered by reference to absolute, immutable standards, but will usually itself depend in turn on other “questions of degree”.
In Vacuum Oil Co Pty Ltd v Ashfield Municipal Council (1956) 2 LGRA 8 at 11 , Sugerman J offered the following observations on the concept of “amenity” in town planning legislation:

“Amenity” is not confined to the negative factor of freedom from physical discomfort through the effects of noise, smell, and the other matters referred to in the proviso to clause 27 of the “County of Cumberland Planning Scheme Ordinance.” It relates also to the preservation of such characteristics of a neighbourhood as make it pleasing in appearance as well to the passer-by as to the resident, and as well to those across the road, who may be unaffected by noise etc, as to the adjoining and other occupiers on the same side. “Amenity” may be taken to express that element in the appearance or layout of the town and country which makes for a comfortable and pleasant life rather than a mere existence.
See also Humby v Woollahra Municipal Council (1964) 10 LGRA 56 at 65 .

There is no doubt that the concept of amenity is wide and flexible. In my view it may in a particular case embrace not only the effect of a place on the senses, but also the resident’s subjective perception of his locality. Knowing the use to which a particular site is or may be put, may affect one’s perception of amenity.

heading.title: Part 2.4: The effects of the legislative provisions

p.text: A decision-maker must start with the zoning plan. That describes the objective of the zone and for what purposes the zones may be used or entered. It specifies when written permission is required for use or entry.

It is common ground that the entry and use proposed and presently undertaken by the applicants is covered by the permitted purposes of farming of marine resources and the construction and conduct of mooring facilities for vessels provided for in both zones “A” and “B” but that written permission is required.

The objective of the zones under which these purposes are permitted is reasonable general use of the zone although in the Harrier Point case this objective is qualified by the need for conservation of the park while in the Juno Bay case reasonable general use is a qualification of the principal objective of conservation of the park.

Regulation 18(4) guides the authority as to how it is to consider an application under the zoning plan for written permission to enter or use part of the park. Such an activity must first fall within the approved purposes. It is only if the proposed activity is an approved use that the provisions of reg 18(4) arise for consideration and then only when the approved use requires written permission. In the present case the present and proposed activities are approved uses under cll 5.2(b) and 6.2(b)(vii) and (ix) and require written consent. They may also be within cll 5.2(b)(xviii) and 6.2(b)(xix) to the extent that they are not otherwise covered.

The decision-maker must accordingly address the requirements of reg 18(4). This is on the basis that the present and proposed activity is within those capable of being within the objectives for both zones.

The first of the matters which must be addressed under reg 18(4) is the objective of the zone. In the present case that draws attention to whether the activity is a “reasonable general-use consistent with the conservation of the … park” in the case of Harrier Point. In the case of Juno Bay, the question is whether the activity is a “reasonable general-use” which does not compromise “the conservation of the … park” (and which is in an area which is free from trawling and generally free from shipping).
In the present case there is no risk to conservation of the park. The Juno Bay area, and probably the Harrier Point area as well, are free from trawling and generally free from shipping.
The only issue with respect to the objectives of the zones in the present case is whether the use is reasonable general use.

Most aspects of the matters described in the other paragraphs of reg 18(4) are negative matters or matters addressing indications which will usually be contrary to a proposal. Certainly, the principal matters for consideration here such as the need to protect cultural and heritage values and the assessment of the nature and scale of the proposed use in relation to existing use and amenity are such matters.

There is accordingly a tension between the matters to be considered. The items which must be addressed in accordance with reg 18(4) cannot be addressed discretely. What is necessary is a comparative evaluation. Cultural and heritage values and the nature and scale of the proposed use in relation to existing use and amenity, as well as future desirable use and amenity, must be comparatively evaluated against the policy of reasonable general use.

Accordingly, more is required than merely finding that cultural and heritage values are involved. The need to protect them must be set against the proposed use. More is required than finding that the proposed use will interfere with use and amenity. The nature and scale of the proposed use must be judged against existing use and amenity. All of this must be used to aid a determination of what is reasonable use in all the circumstances. In accordance with the United States authorities, in our view correctly, the concept of reasonable use alone requires a balancing of benefits and detriments.

In our opinion the joint requirements to consider “reasonableness” and to value competing considerations of culture and heritage and the effects of changes in use and amenity against a policy of permitting the proposed uses in accordance with the zonings applying here requires a consideration of the actual conditions at the times relevant for consideration by the various decision-makers.
A use which interferes with cultural and heritage values may be unreasonable if it has never been present but reasonable if it has been permitted for many years without opposition.

Administrative decision-makers are generally required to address the evidence before them and not confine themselves to evidence before a prior decision-maker whose decision is being reviewed unless the relevant legislation requires a decision to be based upon the circumstances at a particular point of time: Australian Tea Tree Oil Research Institute v Industry Research and Development Board (2002) 124 FCR 316 at 324–6 ; 70 ALD 1 at 8–10 ; Comptroller-General of Customs v Akai Pty Ltd (1994) 50 FCR 511 at 521 ; Jebb v Repatriation Commission (1988) 80 ALR 329 at 333 . In Jebb, at 333 , approved by Stone J in Australian Tea Tree Oilat FCR 325 ; ALD 9, Davies J described decision-making in the tribunal as generally a “continuum” in which “the tribunal considers the applicant’s entitlement from the date of application, or other proper commencing date, to the date of the tribunal’s decision”.

heading.title: Part 2.5: Joint management and the park

p.text: Joint management possibilities for the park were put on a legislative footing, following amendments to the Act in 1995: Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Act 1995 (Cth). Accordingly, the Act provides that:

the authority may enter into an agreement or arrangement for the purposes of the Act with a group of people who are representative of a community group that has a special interest in an area of the park: s 39ZA(1);

the agreement or arrangement may relate to the development and/or the implementation of a plan of management for a species or ecological community, and may provide for joint management with the authority in accordance with the plan: s 39ZA(2); and

a reference to a community group having a special interest in an area of the park includes a reference to the people in the group who have some form of native title to the area or its resources or have some other special identification with the area or its resources: s 39V(1).

The steps that might ameliorate the impact of the pearl farm operations in Juno Bay on “cultural and heritage values” need to be considered in the context of the professional opinion expressed by Nicholaas Heijm in his report (at pp 680–1):

Nevertheless, the overriding issue was not the damage to [cultural heritage] values related to the physical intrusion of the pearl farm sites as such — which all parties might well concede will occur if the Indian Pacific Pearls and Zen Pearls project proceeds — but the lack of respect shown by the proprietors of the project and the Authority. As the meeting pointed out, Palm Islands [P]eople have had no part and have been offered no part in negotiating the conditions of the project. No one has sought their consent for use of sea country over which they have both traditional jurisdiction and a historically continuous tradition of use. Instead, they have been confronted with what amounts to a fait accompli — for the pearl farm is there — and asked to deliver up values that have already been violated so that the Authority might consider their “protection” …
All of it is linked to country. That is why Aboriginal law most demands is the recognition of identity and jurisdiction that comes with being asked about the use of Country.
We have commented on other aspects of Mr Heijm’s professional opinion in regard to the conflict over the presence of the pearl farm in traditional waters earlier in our decision.

This opinion was also reflected in the oral evidence given by Walter Palm Island and Erykah Kyle in which they stated that they believed the presence of the pearl farms in Juno Bay and Harrier Point to be a form of invasion causing intrusion and disturbance and that the pearl farms represented a barrier that would change their way of life.
In his report, Nicolaas Heijm expressed the following opinion (at pp 685–6):

In my opinion, the clear course available to the Authority is to develop a working relationship with the Palm Islands community aimed at negotiating management plans that allow the participation of the Palm Islands community in decision making processes, management and policing over their traditional seas. These negotiations would need to be carried with Manbarra traditional owners, with the Bwgcolman Peoples and with the Palm Island Council. Their most likely format would be in terms of a regional agreement or indigenous sea use agreement process.
No such possibility has been considered here. Perhaps it should be. However, that is not a matter for us in determining these applications.

heading.title: Part 3.1: reg 18(4)(a): Objective of the zone

p.text: Neither the Manbarra People nor the authority relied on submissions that the pearling operations threatened the conservation of the park. Mr Crimp’s submission that only a small area of Juno Bay was used by his operation and that the natural resources in the area were being utilised on a renewable basis was not opposed. Several submissions were made in relation to whether the pearling operation was in keeping with the zone’s objective of “providing opportunities for reasonable general-use”.

Mr Crimp submitted that there was no evidence of his pearl farm interfering with the general use of the area by the people of Palm Island over the last 6 years, particularly in respect of initiation practices and school camps. He emphasised that his employees adhered to a strict code of conduct prohibiting them from accessing or carrying out activities over the Palm Island People’s favoured foraging areas or initiation areas.

Mr Crimp submitted that the oral evidence before the tribunal indicated that the traditional inhabitants had little sympathy for commercial operations requiring infrastructure on the basis that they represented a barrier to movement. Nevertheless, he contended that it could not be said that the pearl farms violated or compromised the integrity of the land and seascape at Juno Bay because at no time in almost 6 years had he been asked to mitigate any impact on traditional values. Mr Crimp also contended that the Baer Report demonstrated that foraging and hunting were available elsewhere in the Palm Islands.

The Manbarra People contended that the pearl farms were not consistent with “reasonable general-use” of Juno Bay. The bay was used as a safe harbour for boats in the area and was a favoured fishing area. They submitted that the pearl farms constrained the movement of vessels, the general use of the area for fishing and hunting, and the transient, though reasonably heavy, recreational use of Juno Bay.

The Manbarra People submitted that the presence of the pearl farm adversely affected the integrity of a pristine land and seascape. They submitted that the waters of Juno Bay, and the deeper waters of Harrier Point, contained a vast array of marine foods that formed the staple diet for a significant number of Manbarra and Bwgcolman People. The waters of Juno Bay were considered by those peoples to be their most important fishing place. In addition, they submitted that traditional sea medicines existed in Juno Bay.

The Manbarra People referred to the evidence that Fantome Island was regularly used for camping with Aboriginal people staying for periods varying from weeks to months. In addition, Fantome Island continued to be used for contemporary teaching and inculturation.
The Manbarra People submitted that the pearl farming activities of Mr Crimp would affect the amenity of existing, traditionally based uses at Juno Bay because:
Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples in the area would not be able to participate in the traditional practices of their ancestors and to commune with them; and
their enjoyment of the quiet, peacefulness, solitude, tranquillity and escape offered by Fantome Island, and its adjacent and surrounding waters, would be impaired and compromised.

The Manbarra submitted that it was significant to recognise that the range of the traditionally used marine foraging areas in these waters had decreased over time. For example, the presence of the national park on Orpheus Island. In addition, it needed to be recognised that wind patterns from May–September made hunting and fishing difficult and dangerous in these waters with Juno Bay the only place in the Palm Island group that had a combination of calm waters and a substantial fringing reef.

The authority did not seek to raise any conservation issue. It conceded that there was no effective evidence that the sites of the pearl farms had caused practical difficulties for the use of the bay by either indigenous or other peoples. It contended that the issue for the tribunal to decide was one of values rather than use.

The authority disputed the Manbarra People’s interpretation of the zones: they noted that the main difference between general use “A” and “B” zones was that general use “B” zones were to be free from trawling and generally free from shipping. The Manbarra had contended that the objective of general use “B” zones was more heavily weighted towards the conservation of the park and that the general use “A” zone was more permissive of opportunities for reasonable general use.
The principal matter we must consider under this part of the regulation is reasonable general use in the context of the other matters arising for our consideration as outlined above.

heading.title: Part 3.2: reg 18(4)(b): Cultural and heritage values

p.text: It was contended that the regulatory requirement for the need to protect cultural and heritage values at the Juno Bay site was the paramount issue for our consideration.

heading.title: Part 3.2.1: Status of the Manbarra People

p.text: The first issue that arose in relation to traditional values was what standing the Manbarra People had to agitate the issue on behalf of the Palm Island community. Counsel for the Manbarra People contended that the following issues were not in dispute between the parties:
that the Manbarra People and the Bwgcolman People are Aboriginal people comprising “traditional inhabitants” who hold cultural and heritage values in relation to the park; and
that those people live in the central zone of the park including living, for extended periods, on Fantome Island.

Counsel for the Manbarra People contended that members of the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People held cultural and heritage values in relation to that part of the park that comprised the waters surrounding the Palm Island group. He submitted that the Manbarra People had a recognised authority structure as well as decision-making processes. He submitted that the Manbarra People were recognised by the Bwgcolman People as being the traditional owners under the Aboriginal tradition in the region. In turn, the Manbarra People took into account the interests of the Bwgcolman People in relation to the Juno Bay area and did so in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. He further contended that under Aboriginal tradition, the Manbarra People had the primary right to speak for the relevant areas in the park and did so, following consultation with the Bwgcolman People. Counsel for the Manbarra People submitted that the Aboriginal tradition had its foundation in a core value through an identity with country as well as the idea that there was a traditional owner of the country. The core value had spiritual and intellectual dimensions. Connection with country, including waters, was fundamental to the identity and existence of both the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples as those peoples shared the traditional estate of the Palm Islands. Counsel submitted that the young people on Palm Island had not abandoned core traditional values.

Written submissions prepared by Mr Crimp’s solicitor had declined to admit the existence of the Manbarra People as an identifiable group. At the hearing Mr Crimp made several concessions about the existence of the Manbarra People and cultural and heritage values in respect of Juno Bay. He submitted that these concessions were delayed because the particulars he had sought were not provided until Mr Heijm gave his oral evidence at the tribunal hearing. The Heijm Report appeared to accept that there were traditional owners but did not provide any genealogies. Requests for particulars of these matters had been made since 1997 but had not been responded to.

In relation to the Heijm Report, Mr Crimp contended that the details or demographics of the people consulted were unclear: for example, the number of elders, other older participants, men, women and young people. Consequently the question of representativeness of the opinion expressed in the report was in issue, in terms of the values contained in the report.

Counsel for the authority submitted that a review of the evidence and information before the tribunal, including concessions made by Mr Crimp during cross-examination, indicated that there were a group of people who might be characterised as “traditional inhabitants”. They were the Manbarra People who had inhabited the Palm Island group from at least the latter part of the nineteenth century, and the Bwgcolman People, a separate group of people who have lived on Palm Island since the early twentieth century after being forcibly removed there from the mainland. The land and waters of the Palm Island group was the “country” of those peoples in the broad sense.

In written submissions the Manbarra People contended that whether or not persons are “traditional inhabitants” is not a threshold issue. This was disputed by the authority who said that it was important to determine whether persons were traditional inhabitants because special considerations may arise in respect of such persons compared to other persons.

All of this went to whether it was appropriate for the Manbarra People to raise this issue before the tribunal. It is also relevant to the impact of the pearling operations on the economic interests of the Palm Island community and also to the consultation with the Palm Island community.

heading.title: Part 3.2.2: Cultural and heritage values requiring protection

p.text: We will begin considering the protection of cultural and heritage values by outlining the values which the Manbarra People claim must be protected by refusing to permit the pearling operations. Counsel for the Manbarra People submitted that the impact of Mr Crimp’s activities would diminish a number of cultural and heritage values — values which, when combined with a richness of environment and a totality of experience derived from Aboriginal tradition, were not available anywhere else in the Palm Island group. These values included values associated with:
traditional marine foraging areas;
places associated with culturally valued activities such as contemporary teaching/inculturation practices; and
places immanent of and sacralized by ancestral presence and which were not governed by physical boundaries: for example, stopping at the reef.

The authority made its own submissions on the “cultural and heritage values” held by the traditional inhabitants of the area. In this regard, the area of Juno Bay was a traditional and favoured hunting and fishing ground as it was a relatively undisturbed protected shallow bay. Furthermore, Juno Bay had cultural values related to its proximity to the cemeteries and the former hospital site.

It is apparent from the submissions that the protection of the values of seeking permission to enter an area and of consulting with elders and making decisions with community consent were also at issue.

Mr Preston contended that the cultural and heritage values extended from the waters and surrounds of Juno Bay to include values and behavioural protocols relating to ancestors and burial sites. It was his contention that the Aboriginal people in the area felt a sense of sanctity in the spiritual presence of ancestors buried in the two cemeteries on Fantome Island located on either side of the pearl farm in Juno Bay — not only because of the presence of the cemeteries, but also independently and particularly in Juno Bay because most families living on Palm Island today have ancestors buried on Fantome Island.

The Manbarra People submitted that an obligation to seek permission to go to someone else’s country was a core value derived from Aboriginal tradition. Central to this core value was a continuing respect for elders. They submitted that introducing people to the area was a “more localised” tradition intended to protect people in the area.

The Manbarra People submitted that the pearl farms commenced operation without the consent of the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples and thereby challenged the authority and responsibility of those peoples for an integral part of the traditional estate under traditional law and custom. It was his contention that the effect of traditional rules applying to hunting not being followed or broken would lead to the natural order in the area being disrupted and, possibly, harm to the community.

Mr Crimp submitted that the area could not exclusively be the country of the Palm Island Peoples as the power to manage the area was vested in government and there were numerous other users of the area.

The Manbarra People submitted that relevant “cultural and heritage” values need not be held “specifically in relation to the particular area” of the proposed permits but may be held in relation to “any part of the Marine Park”. They also emphasised the absence of any limitation that the values be “special” or “specific” cultural heritage values.

There were differences as to whether or not Juno Bay was a unique place. It was Mr Crimp’s contention that the cultural and heritage values at Juno Bay and the presence of grave sites and settlements at Fantome Island were not unique. Similar traditional values had been identified on most of the other islands in the grant in trust as well as other islands in the Palm Island group.

Mr Preston submitted that Mr Heijm’s report was relevant to whether there were other places in the Palm Island group where people conduct the same activities that they would at Juno Bay. Specifically, it was the “totality of experience”, an “entire range of values” that people experienced on Fantome Island that was not available anywhere else which was important. Further, the isolation from the community on Fantome did create what was probably a “unique place” within the Palm Island group. Moreover, it was a relevant consideration that the applicant’s business plan did not take these cultural and ancestral values into account.
Mr Fellows submitted that, in the tribunal’s evaluation of the area to protect cultural and heritage values at the Juno Bay site, the following matters were relevant considerations:
that the Juno Bay site was relatively undisturbed. Development had occurred on other land, or on other parts of the Palm Island group, for example Great Palm Island and Orpheus Island;
that the zoning plan restricted use and entry into parts of the Palm Island group of islands, for example, the park “A” and “B” zones. In addition, there was a state national park on Orpheus Island;
that Fantome Island was unique in the Palm Island group because of the presence of grave sites and former settlement sites; and
that Juno Bay had an extensive protected reef that was a traditional and favoured hunting and fishing ground.

heading.title: Part 3.2.4: Impact of future development on traditional values

p.text: Mr Crimp submitted that the values of Juno Bay would not be further diminished as the pearl farm operation moved to full production because the existing infrastructure and personnel would remain much the same as it had been in the preceding 6 years. In addition, the visual impact would not significantly change notwithstanding the need to introduce a 25–30 m accommodation/laboratory boat. Mr Crimp submitted that the pearl farms would offer employment opportunities.

The authority submitted that as pearl farm operations at the Juno Bay site expanded, over time, into full-time production, the site could become an “industrial site” because of the continuous flow of employees and the presence of a larger vessel on site. Disturbance of the values held for this site would be a consequence. The authority submitted that because of the applicant’s needs for: (i) a larger accommodation/laboratory boat to be moored at Juno Bay; and (ii) the use of surface lines with accompanying buoys — rather than sub-surface lines as originally intended, it would not be possible to manage or to minimise the impacts on visual disturbance that would arise. Mr Crimp admitted that the use of surface lines was a “commercial decision” in breach of his permit. He said surface lines had been used for a “long time with a number of site inspections” and agreed that additional equipment and labour would be required to use sub-surface lines.

Mr Crimp’s site development plan noted an “intention to moor surplus vessels at Harrier Point to reduce impact”. However, these would not include the 25–30 m accommodation vessel, or at least not permanently. Mr Crimp said he might “take it out there for a day or two … and then bring it back”.

heading.title: Part 3.3: reg 18(4)(c): Future options for the park

p.text: The Manbarra submitted that future options for the area would be restricted if the permits were granted in that:
the use of the sites by traditional inhabitants would be restricted and inhibtted;
Juno Bay would not be available for use by the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People for their own commercial operations.

The Manbarra submitted that there was a policy embedded in the Act (ss 10(1)(b), 39V(1), 39Y and 39ZA) and the Regulations (reg 18(4)(b) and (5)), and in policy documents and publications, directed to the recognition and protection of the interests, cultural and heritage values and co-management aspirations of indigenous people with attachments to the marine park. They submitted that it was also relevant that the Palm Islands group, home to approximately 2000 indigenous people, was subject to the only grant in trust affecting land within the park’s boundaries.

Mr Crimp contended that there was no evidence or justification for a conclusion that future use by the traditional inhabitants would be compromised or that use by recreational boating users or fishermen would be compromised.

The authority accepted Mr Crimp’s submissions in relation to the Harrier Point site, but said that the in-shore location of the Zen Pearls proposal would compromise the future use of Juno Bay by all persons particularly to the extent that it alienates a significant portion of Juno Bay by granting almost exclusive use of the area to Zen Pearls.

Mr Crimp submitted that the amenity of Juno Bay had not been affected by the pearling operations to date. The area was used by a number of non-indigenous users, such as government, private and commercial users, none of whom had complained that the pearl farm operations affected their enjoyment or the values of the area. Mr Crimp considered the pearl farms to now be a part of the seascape. Moreover, the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People had, and would continue to have, unimpeded private access to Juno Bay.

Mr Crimp’s position is that, after 6 years presence, the pearl farm operations have not violated the integrity of the land and seascape of Fantome Island — there have been no incidents and he has not been asked to mitigate any impact on traditional values.

The position of the authority was that at this time, there was no evidence that the site of the pearl farm in Juno Bay had caused practical difficulties for the use of the bay by indigenous or other people.

However, on behalf of the Manbarra, Mr Preston’s position was that the quiet, peacefulness, solitude, tranquillity and escape offered by Fantome Island and its adjacent and surrounding waters for the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People have been impaired and compromised. As a consequence, the pearl farming operations at Juno Bay affect the amenity of existing, traditional activities at Juno Bay.

Mr Crimp acknowledged that an additional source of conflict may arise in the future through the need to moor a 12 m and a 25–30 m vessel, together with staff, as well as necessary security at the site. Nevertheless he contended that the visual impact would not significantly increase notwithstanding the need to introduce a large accommodation laboratory boat.

The Manbarra People submitted that future amenity and use of the area would be further impaired and compromised by the proposed new vessels, staff and security. They submitted that the presence of 15 long lines (some surface, some midwater) at the 10 ha Juno Bay site would make traverses across the site impossible and thereby exclude users from the area. Moreover, it was their submission that the value of the pearl crop would require physical and human presence on site to ensure security. They contended that the security on site would result in Palm Islanders having to significantly modify the extent of their present activities in the area of the marine park where Mr Crimp carried out his pearling operations.

The authority agreed with Mr Crimp that the nature and scale of Indian Pacific Pearls’ proposed activity was acceptable. However, it said that Zen Pearls’ proposed use of the shallow waters of Juno Bay was not acceptable.

heading.title: Part 3.5: reg 18(4)(f): Adjoining and adjacent areas and the environment

p.text: The Manbarra submit that this regulation, in its context, should be taken to include “social, economic and cultural aspects” and repeat their other submissions.

The Manbarra submitted that the decision-maker may not “take any action that adversely affects, as part of the national estate, a place that is in the register unless [the decision-maker] is satisfied that there is no feasible and prudent alternative, consistent with any relevant laws, to the taking of that action …”: s 30(2) of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 (Cth).

Mr Crimp contended that neither proposal would affect a place that is in the register of the national estate to a significant extent for the purpose of s 30(2). Mr Crimp disputed the claim that no reasonable measures could be taken to minimise any alleged adverse effect of the proposal on the physical and cultural environment of the places.

The authority conceded that the Indian Pacific Pearls proposal was unlikely to affect a place on the register to a significant extent. However, it said that the Zen Pearls proposal was likely to affect such a place and that no reasonable measures could be taken to minimise the adverse effect of the proposal.

There was no evidence before us as to what national estate values represented in Juno Bay or at Harrier Point led to that part of the reef area being placed on the register of the national estate. This matter was only given slight attention by the parties. It is accordingly difficult for us to address the issue.

The Manbarra submitted that an applicant’s financial interests or commercial opportunities are not relevant considerations. The authority did not dispute this except with the qualification that general use “A” and “B” zones clearly recognise that commercial activity may, with a relevant permission, take place in such zones.

Mr Fellows contended that the applicant was aware of the commercial risks associated with the ongoing needs for their pearl farm operations in the marine park, but had chosen not to make any contingency plans in the event that a renewal permit was not granted by the authority.

Mr Fellows submitted that in the event we decided to grant a renewal permit at the Juno Bay site that it should be given for the same time period as the Harrier Point site; the Harrier Point permit applied to 1 September 2005. He contended that such an arrangement, with both permits running in tandem, would be effective for ensuring consistency in administrative decision-making as it would mean that the renewal of each permit could be assessed, consistently, by taking into account the experiences of taking small harvests in 2004 and 2005. Furthermore, Mr Fellows contended that there was a need to recognise that there was no evidence before the tribunal, including any statement of issues, that had considered the question of a lengthier permit.

Mr Fellows concluded with the submission that the delay in the hearing of this application for review had arisen from actions by the applicants as much as by others. However, it was his contention that had Mr Crimp acknowledged much earlier than at the hearing before this tribunal, the existence of the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People, including that they held cultural and heritage values, his application for review could have been heard much earlier and confined to fewer disputed issues.

Mr Crimp said that without the Juno Bay site, the pearl farm operations at Harrier Point would not be viable as there was no way to work at the latter site under all weather conditions. He said that in these circumstances he would have no other option than “to pack up and go”. Mr Crimp said that he had no contingency plans for the pearls should this situation arise.

An issue that arose which relates to the interests of the traditional inhabitants but which does not easily fall within reg 18(4)(b) is encroachment upon the economic resources of the Palm Island community. Mr Crimp suggested that the pearling operations could not be represented as part of any continued encroachment on economic development. He submitted that after 6 years of operations, the pearl farm did not appear to have impaired community aspirations for Fantome Island that were dependent on maintaining the integrity of the sea. He said the Baer Report demonstrated that activities of spiritual importance and traditional foraging and hunting could be conducted elsewhere in the Palm Island group.

We have taken the matters specified in reg 18(4) (a), (b), (c), (e) and (f) into account, but we have also had regard to all of the other matters specified in reg 18(4). We have done so on the basis of all the material before the tribunal. We accept the evidence of the indigenous witnesses. Where we have not expressly rejected it we accept all the evidence given before us which we have set out above. We have not interrupted the flow of our account of the facts by making references to findings. It may be taken that references to facts or evidence in these reasons amount to findings of fact unless we have stated otherwise. In this section, however, we will make more specific findings of fact. Facts and matters referred to in this section are accepted by us.
We will first address traditional cultural and heritage values as required by reg 18(4)(b).

We find that Aboriginal people — the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples live in the Palm Island group. Furthermore, the evidence of Walter Palm Island, Edward Nullanjar and Ralph Norman makes it quite clear that the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples use Fantome Island for traditional purposes and to pursue traditional values — as well as living there for periods throughout the year.

We accept the opinion evidence of Nicolaas Heijm that the Palm Islands are the traditional jurisdiction of a contemporary traditional owner group who are the “original people” of the Palm Islands in Aboriginal law and tradition in the region and that these “original people” are descended from the antecedent traditional owners. In recent times, this group has been known as “the Manbarra tribe or Manbarra People”. The home country of the Manbarra People includes the island group, the adjacent reefs and the intervening and surrounding seas. We accept that the Palm Island concept of “country” makes no distinction between the islands and the seas.

We accept the opinion of Nicolaas Heijm that, in addition to Manbarra People, other Aboriginal people live in the Palm Island group of islands. Since the 1930s, these Aboriginal people have been known as the Bwgcolman People. The Bwgcolman People are descended from at least 5000 people transported to the Palm Island reserve, between 1918–71, from all parts of Queensland, the Torres Strait and Melanesian Islands.

Ralph Norman’s evidence was that he had been taught about Manbarra tradition by successive Manbarra elders over time. Erykah Kyle’s evidence makes it quite clear that the Manbarra People were the traditional owners of the land and the seas and that Bwgcolman People did not speak for Manbarra. Edward Nullanjar and Ralph Norman, as members of the Bwgcolman People, also acknowledged the Manbarra as the traditional owners of the Palm Islands and the waters of Juno Bay.

Based on the evidence of Erykah Kyle, Edward Nullanjar, Ralph Norman and Nicolaas Heijm, we conclude that, in contrast to the Manbarra People, the Bwgcolman People cannot, and do not, claim traditional ownership of Palm Island; but trace their origin and peoples to the moment their social identity became part of Palm Island. Furthermore, we accept that the indigenous evidence before the tribunal is consistent with the expert opinion evidence in the following regard: that the expression of Bwgcolman identity is partly based on the sea and its products reflecting the teaching of the ways of the sea to Bwgcolman People as an essential part of Manbarra tradition.

In its consideration of the park regulatory controls imposed by reg 18(4)(b) with respect to “cultural and heritage values” we have relied on the meaning of “cultural heritage” as applied in Tickner v Bropho to mean the language, traditions, customs, stories and religions of peoples past and present. In addition, we have applied the reasoning in Chapman v Luminis Pty Ltd (No 4) with respect to the notice of Aboriginal tradition, and in particular, the meaning of “tradition, observances, customs or beliefs”. We specifically rely upon the notion that it involves a handing down from generation to generation in accordance with the accepted way in which Aboriginal history, laws, observances and practices are transmitted over time.

The evidence of Erykah Kyle, Ralph Norman and Edward Nullanjar makes it clear that the country on Palm Island was the traditional estate of the Manbarra People and that the Bwgcolman share in that estate according to Manbarra tradition. We accept Walter Palm Island’s evidence that there are localised traditions, customs, beliefs and rules that are handed down throughout the community to ensure knowledge and laws are passed on. Furthermore, we find the indigenous evidence that, under traditional law, the Manbarra should be asked permission by people who wish to use the waters of the Palm Islands, to be consistent with the traditions. We accept it.

We accept the opinion evidence of Nicolaas Heijm that the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples live according to traditions, observances, customs and beliefs that are underpinned by specific characteristics such as:
an identity with country that has spiritual and intellectual dimensions;
that the country on Palm Island was the traditional estate of the Manbarra People;
that the Bwgcolman share in the traditional estate under Manbarra tradition;
the need to ask permission to go to another’s country; and
the existence of a range of localised traditions and rituals.

We accept Mr Heijm’s opinion evidence that these traditions, observances, customs and beliefs have been handed down from generation to generation throughout the community of Palm Island (including to young people) in accordance with Aboriginal history, laws, practices and observations.

We find that the observations made by Lockhart J in Wamba Wamba Local Aboriginal Land Council with respect to burial sites, Aboriginal tradition and the requirements for peace and tranquillity together with the need to be free from intrusion by humans, are consistent with the evidence of Walter Palm Island, Erykah Kyle, Edward Nullanjar and Ralph Norman. We refer specifically to their evidence with respect to the sacred value of Fantome Island, as well as the presence of ancestral spirits and forces in the landscape of Fantome Island. We accept their evidence that this place is sacred to them because of the spiritual presence of ancestors. In addition, we accept that the traditional way for showing respect to ancestors is to talk to them and to acknowledge that they are in the area when passing through. Moreover, we find that respect for their ancestors’ previous lives is reflected in the need for quiet and to be free of unnecessary noise.
We find the graves on Fantome Island to be places of “special ancestral presence” and that the domain or range of the spirits could carry some distance from the land on Fantome Island.

Based, in part, on the evidence of Erykah Kyle and Nicolaas Heijm we conclude that the sacred values associated with the presence of ancestral spirits and forces on Fantome Island make it a unique place in the Palm Island group because of:
the “totality of experience for traditional inhabitants” providing them with spiritual experiences about who they were and their connection with ancestors and the land;
the existence of an “entire range of traditional values”; and
the absence of any other equivalent site for the traditional inhabitants of the Palm Island group where the totality of experience or range of values could be experienced.

We find the evidence of Walter Palm Island, Edward Nullanjar and Ralph Norman to state consistently that the waters of Juno Bay were a favoured fishing ground. Their evidence was corroborated by the research of Nicolaas Heijm as contained in his report.

Next we have considered the evidence of Walter Palm Island, Edward Nullanjar and Ralph Norman and the legal principles in Mason v Tritton in regard to traditional fishing rights and conclude that fishing is a traditional activity for the Manbarra and Bwgcolman People based upon traditional laws and customs. We find that the traditional inhabitants’ laws and customs extend to the right to fish. The Palm Islanders have continued to observe the relevant laws and customs and their conduct or activity in fishing in Juno Bay is an exercise of those traditional laws and customs.

However, the significance of this finding of fact is that there is no evidence before us that traditional fishing rights have been adversely affected by the pearl farm operations at the Juno Bay site at this stage. Accordingly, we simply find that the presence of the pearl farm in Juno Bay may have potential to interfere with traditional rights to hunt and to fish in Juno Bay.

We recognise that Mr Crimp has taken steps with staff employed at his pearl farm to ensure that operations at the pearl farm do not conflict or compete with traditional activities undertaken in the Juno Bay area. However, Mr Crimp has acknowledged that there is no co-management plan in place between his companies and the local community in order to protect “cultural and heritage values”.

Based on the above findings and, in the context of the absence of any form of mutually agreed plan of co-management for cultural and heritage values between the Manbarra and Bwgcolman Peoples and the applicant companies for pearl farm operations, in our evaluation of reg 18(4)(b) we find that there is a need to protect the cultural and heritage values held by traditional inhabitants in relation to the pearl farm sites.

The next issue for us to deal with relates to the nature and scale of the pearl farm operations at Juno Bay in relation to existing use and amenity — as well as the future or desirable use and amenity of Juno Bay and nearby areas: reg 18(4)(e).

We consider that the meaning of “amenity” reflects the qualities or characteristics of a place which make it pleasant and agreeable ( Broad’s case) as well as the need for the preservation of these qualities and characteristics ( Humby’s case). These qualities or characteristics extend to non-marketable or intangible benefits such as beauty and tranquillity.

The existing use and amenity can be contrasted to the impacts on amenity and future use, as the scale of pearl farm operations expands to full production. As operations expand, Mr Crimp will require a much larger accommodation/laboratory boat which he states can only be moored at Juno Bay. Such a vessel would be up to 35 m and would need to accommodate eight full-time staff, increasing to 14 staff during periods of seeding and harvesting. Mr Crimp’s evidence is that it would not be practicable to moor such a vessel at the off-shore pearl farm at Harrier Point because exposure at this deepwater site would not make it possible to live and work at the site. In addition, surface lines with accompanying buoys would be used — rather than sub-surface lines as originally intended. Moreover, the increasing value of the pearl crop over time would necessitate full-time physical presence to ensure security on site — a fact acknowledged by Mr Crimp.

We find that the inhabitants of Great Palm Island hold cultural and heritage values in relation to Fantome Island including the waters of Juno Bay and off Harrier Point which will be affected by continued pearl farming by Indian Pacific Pearls and Zen Pearls. These values are held by the inhabitants of Great Palm Island as traditional inhabitants and involve Aboriginal traditions. The values relate both to beliefs and practices. The beliefs involve spiritual beliefs such as the need to respect deceased ancestors buried on Fantome Island and the need to seek the consent of traditional owners before entering upon another’s country. The practices involve fishing, gathering and hunting, including traditional fishing, gathering and hunting. We have already made our detailed findings on this. These cultural and heritage values require consideration under reg 18(4).

Even if the cultural and heritage values were not held as part of Aboriginal tradition, and even if we are wrong in considering the inhabitants of Great Palm Island to be traditional inhabitants, the cultural and heritage values we have found the inhabitants to hold would still require consideration under reg 18(4) because the regulation applies equally to other people as it does to traditional inhabitants and it does not require even the cultural and heritage values of traditional inhabitants to be based upon Aboriginal tradition.

We also find that the nature and scale of the present pearl farming as well as its proposed expansion affects the existing use and amenity as well as the future and desirable use and amenity of Juno Bay and the waters off Harrier Point. This affectation relates to the impact on movement, site and sound. The visual impact of the pearl farming is the major impact, but noise and interference with movement are also involved. This impact is substantial from any point of view but is especially adverse from the point of view of Aboriginal inhabitants in accordance with Aboriginal traditions.

To our minds both the effect on the cultural and traditional values we have found and the effect on existing use and amenity viewed both from an ordinary perspective and from the perspective of the traditional inhabitants should each have been enough to result in the original applications for permits to use the two sites for pearl farming to be refused. The cultural and heritage values present in the area before any pearl farming took place required protection to the extent of the refusal of permission. The nature and scale of even the pearl farming as it was first proposed in relation to the then existing use and amenity required the same result. On both grounds the use proposed at the time of the original applications was not reasonable general-use, notwithstanding that it was a permitted use under the zoning plan.

So far we have not distinguished the Juno Bay site from the Harrier Point site. The differences between the two seem to us to be differences of degree. Undoubtedly, the Juno Bay site attracts all the considerations we have addressed in much stronger terms than the Harrier Point site. The case against the use of Juno Bay for pearl farming is stronger than the case against Harrier Point. But virtually all the elements present for Juno Bay are, to some extent, present for Harrier Point. Whether one looks at cultural and heritage values or existing use and amenity the relevant elements, including activities or beliefs, are all tied to the matters of movement, view and noise to which we have referred. All these are present for Harrier Point as they are for Juno Bay. The only difference is distance. We do not think that it can be said that pearl farming at Juno Bay is not reasonable general use although it is reasonable at Harrier Point. In any event, Mr Crimp has unequivocally informed us that he would not attempt to continue pearl farming at Harrier Point alone if he were prevented from using Juno Bay. Accordingly, this matter is largely academic.

It follows that the original permits should not have been granted. However, we are not considering initial applications for permits. Those applications were successful although only with permits for 12 months. We are considering applications for permits which are, in effect, to continue an existing pearl farming operation which proceeded with consent. It is true that the Manbarra People made applications for review, in this tribunal, of the decision to grant the original permits but they did not pursue those applications. It may be that they believed that precisely the same issues would arise in applications for review of the decisions currently before us but the legal and practical consequences of not pursuing the original applications cannot be ignored. The legal consequence is that permits to farm at both sites were granted and that the applicant companies commenced pearl farming pursuant to the permits. The practical consequence is that the applicant companies have been allowed to carry on their pearl farming for a longer period of time than if the original applications for review had not been discontinued. The applications for review of the original permits would have been heard and determined long ago. In fact the applicant companies have now been farming the areas for 6 years with only a maximum of 2 years remaining under the one current permit under review, unless we grant an extension of that permit.

The delay in these proceedings coming on for hearing has been the doing of the parties. While the applicant companies may have encouraged delay with the hope that some agreement may be reached it cannot be said that neither the authority nor the Manbarra People bear no share of the responsibility. They could have applied to the tribunal for the matter to be brought quickly on for hearing at any time.

Nor is it entirely irrelevant that at the time the original permits were granted and when the applications for review of those permits were on foot it was clear that the applicant companies proposals were long-term and could not be viable or produce any commercial return unless the original permits were extended for up to 12 years. Against this it must be said that Mr Crimp was always aware of the risk. We do not accept that he was promised by the authority that the original permits would be extended. In any event he knew that the ultimate decision was always going to be the decision of the tribunal.

It seems to us that the circumstances occurring since the grant of the original permits are capable of affecting the question of whether permits could be granted for pearl farming which would amount to reasonable general use. In particular we think that the fact that the pearl farming has been taking place now for 6 years without significant trouble is relevant. We refer to Jebb’s case and the cases referred to with it, above. We say this knowing that the pearl farming at Juno Bay has not been formally authorised other than by a stay of proceedings. We know that the pearl companies’ unauthorised conduct cannot itself provide a base for them to be permitted to continue that conduct. We recognise, however, that the parties knew that the consequence of the grant of the stay would be that the pearl farming would continue. We are also aware that the applicant companies are not complying with the terms of either the original permits or the permit under review because their principal vessel used on the pearl farm is moored at Juno Bay and not Harrier Point and because many of the long lines are surface lines and not midwater lines.
